Nkosi, F.T.T. Ng*, G.L. Rempel Department of Chemical Engineering, University of Waterloo, 200 University Avenue West, Waterloo, Ont., Canada N2L 3G! Received 12 July 1996; received in revised form 22 November 1996; accepted 29 December 1996 Abstract A number of catalysts were prepared by exchanging NaY zeolite with various amounts of nickel (NiNaY) as well as partially exchanging NaY zeolite with alkali and alkaline-earth cations (M) followed by nickel promotion (NiMNaY). These catalysts were used to oligomerize butenes in the liquid phase. For the NiMNaY catalysts prepared from similar concentrations of nickel chloride, the nickel loading decreased with increase in the cationic size of M. The acidity of catalysts was measured using temperature programmed desorption of ammonia. The NiNaY catalysts showed an increase in acid concentration with nickel loading. For the NiMNaY catalysts, a linear correlation between the acid concentration and the Sanderson electronegativity of M was found. The oligomerization activity of NiNaY and NiMNaY catalysts increased with nickel loading and acidity. It was observed that the increase in activity also led to an increase in the deactivation rate. This is attributed to the increased adsorption of olefins on the more acidic catalysts leading to the formation of long chain oligomers that foul the catalysts. For the catalysts with similar activities, the dimer selectivity was found to increase with cationic size of M, but decreased with increase in Sanderson's electronegativity of M. This improvement in catalyst stability imparted by M is probably due to the partial blocking of windows for the hexagonal prisms and/or sodalite cages of the nickel exchanged catalysts. The NiCsNaY catalyst was found to be an almost exclusive dimer selective catalyst and has the lowest deactivation rate. Keywords: Nickel exchanged Y-zeolite; Partially exchanged alkali NaY zeolites; Butene dimerization; Oligomerization; Catalyst deactivation; Acidity; Sanderson electronegativity 1. Introduction The oligomerization of butenes using nickel ion-exchanged Y-zeolites (NiNaY) has been reported previously [1,2]. These studies indicated that the * Corresponding author. E-mail: fttng@cape.uwaterloo.ca. 0926-860X/97/$17.00 1997 Elsevier Science B.V. All rights reserved. PII S0926-860X(96)00420-6 226 B. Nkosi et al./Applied Catalysis A: General 158 (1997) 225-241 zeolite catalysts were undergoing serious deactivation. Recently [3], we found that NiNaY catalysts derived from various nickel precursor salts had different deactivation rates attributed to differences in surface acidity. In that study it was also found that the reaction was diffusion-rate limited and that catalyst deactivation was due to blocking of pores in the Y-zeolite. There are a number of approaches that have been used to circumvent the deactivation of oligomeriza- tion catalysts [4-7]. One of the approaches is by the choice of a catalyst support system such as the use of large pore supports whereby the reaction would not be diffusion-rate limited and to minimize pore blockage [4,5]. Another approach is to choose zeolite supports with a narrow pore system which would restrict formation of bulky products that eventually lead to the blocking of the pores. This approach has been successfully applied by Miller in making nickel catalysts supported on ZSM-5 modified with Group liB elements such as zinc. These ZSM-5 supported catalysts were used for the oligomerization of propylene in the liquid phase [6]. This study is focused on the effect of incorporating Group IA and IIA cations into the NaY zeolite lattice, followed by nickel promotion on the activity and selectivity of NiMNaY catalysts. This incorporation of cations with various cationic sizes not only modifies the size of the Y-zeolite pores, but also results in the modification of the surface acidity. The modi- fication of the pores is due to the fact that cations from Groups IA and IIA have preference for certain cation site positions in the cages of faujasites [7-9]. In this paper, we report the results of butene oligomerization using NiMNaY catalysts (where M--Group IA cations). The results on the butene oligomerization using NiMNaY catalysts (where M--Group IIA cations) has been reported elsewhere [10] and will be used in this paper for comparison between the effect of Group IA and Group IIA cations on the activity of NiMNaY catalysts. 2. Experimental Unless otherwise stated, all catalysts were made by ion exchange procedures. All chemicals were purchased from Aldrich Chemicals and used without any further purification. 20 g of Linde Y-zeolite (LZ-Y52) from Union Carbide was ion exchanged in a 150 ml 0.5 M aqueous solutions of the appropriate alkaline chloride salts (e.g. LiC1, KC1, RbC1, CsC1) at 80 for 24 h. After the ion-exchange procedure, the zeolites were washed thoroughly with deionized water to get rid of any residual ions which may have been occluded in the zeolite pores. The washed samples were then dried at 110 for over 24 h. A second ion-exchange procedure with 150 ml of 0.5 M aqueous solutions of nickel chloride (pH--5.72) at room temperature was performed; the zeolite and nickel chloride solution were left in contact for 16 h and then filtered. The loaded catalysts were subsequently washed B. Nkosi et al./Applied Catalysis A: General 158 (1997) 225-241 227 with deionized water to get rid of any occluded nickel salt. They were then dried, first in air, under ambient conditions followed by drying in the oven at 110 for over 24 h. Calcination was performed at 500 under dry air for 16 h. X-ray powder diffraction patterns (XRD) were obtained for the NaY zeolite, NiNaY and NiMY (M=Li, Mg) catalysts using a Siemens D 500 X-ray diffractometer with a Cu K~ radiation. Surface area of fresh and spent catalysts were determined by N2 adsorption using the BET method. An Autosorb-1 instrument from Quantachrome was used for the BET measurements. Nickel loadings were determined by X-ray fluorescence (XRF) using an Oxford Lab-X 1000 instrument. The residual sodium contents were determined by atomic absorption spectrometry (AAS) using a Perkin Elmer 3100 instrument. The carbon content of spent catalysts was analyzed by the thermal gravimetric/differential thermal analysis method (TGA/DTA) using an SDT 2960 from TA Instruments, Inc. Approximately 50 mg of spent catalyst samples were heated in a 5% 02 in helium flow up to 650 at 20/min. A fresh calcined catalyst was used as a reference sample in the TGA/DTA analysis to ensure that any weight loss was due to the hydrocarbons or coke found on the spent catalyst. Temperature programmed desorption (TPD) studies were performed in an automated Altamira AMI-1 system. In a typical run, 60 mg of sample, previously calcined at 500 for 12 h under a dry air atmosphere, was heated in flow of argon to 550 at a rate of 20/min and maintained at that temperature for 3 h. By maintaining the catalyst under argon at 550 for 3 h we are certain that the signals obtained up to 550 from TPD studies are not due to water desorbing from the zeolites. Ammonia was adsorbed at 100, the samples were then flushed with argon at 100 for 1.5 h to remove physisorbed ammonia. TPD was performed at a heating rate of 10/min from 100 to 650. Analysis of the reactor effluent was performed using a thermal conductivity detector (TCD). 1-Butene oligomerization reactions were performed in the liquid phase using a 300 ml Parr Autoclave. The autoclave was equipped with a cooling coil to control temperature excursions such that temperature control was within 1 of the desired setpoint. All the oligomerization reactions, unless otherwise stated, were per- formed in a batch reactor using isopentane as solvent under the following standard conditions: Reactor temperature=110; total pressure----600 pounds per square inch (psi); duration of rnn=2 h; isopentane : 1-butene wt ratio--1:2.7; stirring rate=200 rpm. In a typical reaction run, a liquid charge containing 70 g of 1-butene and 25 g of isopentane was contacted with 3 g of catalyst under stirring for 2 h at 110 and 600 psi pressure. At the end of 2 h the reaction products were cooled to about 6 using ice. The amounts of reaction products and some unreacted butenes were weighed, they were then stored in the refrigerator at 8 and subsequently analyzed by gas-liquid chromatography (GC). A 60 m DB-1 column was used to separate the butenes and reaction products. The performance evaluation of catalysts as determined from the GC analysis were as follows: 228 B. Results and discussion 3.1. Nickel and Group IA cation content in NiMNaY catalysts The composition of the nickel supported alkali-exchanged Y-zeolites are shown in Table 1. XRD data showed that there was no change in the crystallinity of these NiMNaY catalysts. The NaY zeolite samples used in this study were extrudates derived from LZ-Y52 powder bonded with 20% w/w alumina. The sodium content of this material was approximately 7.7% w/w (as calculated from Union Carbide specifications). The results show that there is a fair amount of residual sodium cations remaining after the nickel exchange for the NiNaY catalysts (between 29% and 93% of the initial sodium value) and after the two exchange procedures for the NiMNaY catalysts (between 19% and 32% of the initial sodium value). Table 1 also shows that for catalysts prepared from 0.5 M NiC12 solutions, the nickel loading is decreasing with increase in the size of the alkali cation; with the more bulky cesium ion having the lowest nickel loading. This phenomenon is due to the fact that Group IA cations below sodium in the periodic table are known to have a preference for occupying cationic positions in the supercages and only migrate very slowly to the sodalite and hexagonal positions (i.e. the locked positions) at very high temperatures, above 500 [7-9]. On the other hand, nickel cations have preference for occupying locked cationic positions and only start to occupy supercage positions after about 36% of the sites in the hexagonal positions have been exchanged [11]. Since these alkali cations are not easy to displace from the supercage positions, the nickel loading for these catalysts would be expected to be lower. 3.1.1. A similar trend is also observed for the NiMNaY catalysts. For example, for catalysts 1.87NiLiNaY, 1.89NiNaYand 1.50NiCsNaY the less acidic NiCsNaY catalyst yielded the highest amount of linear C8 dimers. The results for the oligomerization of butenes using NiNaY catalysts as given in Table 4 show that the activity increases with nickel loading. It has been reported that when Ni2+ is exchanged for sodium in NaY zeolite, the nickel ions pre- ferentially exchange for sodium ions in the sodalite and hexagonal prisms until about 36% of exchange capacity is reached [11]. After all the exchange sites in these positions are exhausted, the Ni2+ cations then exchange for Na+ cations in the supercages. It has also been proposed that for nickel to be active for the oligomerization reaction, the nickel cations have to be located in the supercages [11]. Since the oligomerization of butenes is acid catalyzed, an increase in acidity due to increased nickel loading is expected to increase oligomerization rate. The effect of acidity on the performance of these NiNaY catalysts for the butene oligomer- ization reaction is shown in Fig. 5. It appears from these results that the oligomerization activity increases with acidity up to a certain level and thereafter starts to level off. The results in Fig. 5 also show that the dimer selectivity decreases with increase in catalyst activity. This result is consistent with a consecutive reaction scheme for the oligomerization of butene. Interestingly, catalyst deactivation, as measured by the loss in surface area as well as by the amount of carbon deposition using TGA, increases with decrease in dimer selectivity (Table 4). These NiMNaY catalysts are less acidic than the NiLiNaY and NiNaY at similar nickel loadings, however, they appear to have higher activities, better dimer selectivities and less deactivation. These phenomena are clearly shown by the NiCsNaY catalyst. The 1.50NiCsNaY catalyst has a similar acidity as the 0.76NiNaY catalyst (Table 2), however, the activity of the NiCsNaY is about double that of 0.71 NiNaY with a 98.2% dimer selectivity and low deactivation. The higher activity with the 1.50NiCsNaY catalysts may be due to the higher nickel content. However, the higher dimer selectivity, and low carbon content on spent catalyst and deactivation is most likely due to the bulky Cs cations preventing the formation of higher oligomers by restricting the space available for longer hydrocarbon chain formation in the zeolite pores. Thus, by partially exchanging sodium with various alkali cations having higher basicity (low Sanderson's electronegativity) and bigger cationic size, catalysts that have good activity with high dimer selectivity and low deactivation are obtained. 3.3. Since barium has a larger radius than lithium, this result indicates that the cationic size has an influence on the dimer selectivity. The influence of cationic size on deactivation is shown in Fig. 10. These results show that the deactivation of the catalysts is inversely proportional to the cationic size. Apparently the alkali and alkaline-earth cations give two different correlation curves, with the less acidic alkali metals having less carbon formation. Some physicochemical properties, such as electrostatic field and potential, have been reported to increase with a decrease in the size of the cation for Faujasite type zeolites exchanged with alkali and alkaline-earth metals [18]. Specifically, these electrostatic factors have a great influence on the diffusivity of polarizable molecules such as alkenes. The results in Fig. 10 could suggest that diffusivity of the alkenes may be influencing the deactivation of these catalysts. The relationship between the carbon content and dimer selectivity is shown in Fig. 11. These results show that the carbon content increases with decrease in the dimer selectivity, suggesting that long chain oligomerization products may be responsible for the fouling of the catalysts. Differential thermal analysis data of the spent NiNaY catalyst indicate that it contains Cs, C12 and C16 hydrocarbons [3]. Other researchers have also concluded that C16 and higher oligomers were responsible for catalyst deactivation [1]. The data in Fig. 11 also appear to fall on two different curves where the spent catalysts derived from K, Rb, and Cs have significantly less carbon and higher selectivity. This may well be due to the lower acidity of these catalysts. Indeed, Fig. 12 shows that the carbon content of spent catalysts increases with an increase in Sanderson's electronegativity. This result is expected since the electronegativity function is related to the acidity of the zeolites and it has been generally accepted that high acidity leads to enhanced catalyst deactivation. It appears that the carbon content increases with Sanderson's electronegativity up to a certain value above which the amount of carbon does not change much. This is related to the observation that the effect of electro- negativity on carbon content of the catalyst is more pronounced for the catalysts derived from the Group IA cations than the Group IIA cations. These results show that the two groups of cations from alkali and alkaline-earth metals form volcano-like curves, with Cs and Ba occupying the apex of the curves. It is interesting to note that the amount of carbon found on the spent catalysts show an inverted volcano-type phenomenon with the Cs and Ba catalysts once again at the apex of the inverted volcano curves (Fig. 14). Conclusions Our results indicate that partially exchanging sodium with other alkali cations in NiNaY leads to catalysts with different activity for 1-butene oligomerization. These differences in oligomerization activity are due to changes in physicochem- ical properties, such as cationic radius and electronegativity of catalysts with the introduction of the different alkali cations. An increase in electronegativity, i.e. acidity, leads to an increase in catalyst deactivation and a decrease in dimer formation. We attribute this to the increase in adsorption of olefins on the more acidic catalysts. An increase in the alkali cationic radius leads to an increase in the dimer selectivity and a decrease in the catalyst deactivation. This phenomenon is attributed to the partial blocking of the windows in the hexagonal prisms and/or sodalite cages by these alkali cations, as well as the influence of the physico- chemical properties of the alkali cations on the diffusivity of the alkenes. The catalyst prepared from partially exchanging sodium with cesium showed the best catalytic performance as evidenced by: high activity, good Cs selectivity and low deactivation rate. A number of catalysts were prepared by exchanging NaY zeolite with various amounts of nickel (NiNaY) as well as partially exchanging NaY zeolite with alkali and alkaline-earth cations (M) followed by nickel promotion (NiMNaY). These catalysts were used to oligomerize butenes in the liquid phase. For the NiMNaY catalysts prepared from similar concentrations of nickel chloride, the nickel loading decreased with increase in the cationic size of M. The acidity of catalysts was measured using temperature programmed desorption of ammonia. The NiNaY catalysts showed an increase in acid concentration with nickel loading. For the NiMNaY catalysts, a linear correlation between the acid concentration and the Sanderson electronegativity of M was found. The oligomerization activity of NiNaY and NiMNaY catalysts increased with nickel loading and acidity. It was observed that the increase in activity also led to an increase in the deactivation rate. This is attributed to the increased adsorption of olefins on the more acidic catalysts leading to the formation of long chain oligomers that foul the catalysts. For the catalysts with similar activities, the dimer selectivity was found to increase with cationic size of M, but decreased with increase in Sanderson's electronegativity of M. This improvement in catalyst stability imparted by M is probably due to the partial blocking of windows for the hexagonal prisms and/or sodalite cages of the nickel exchanged catalysts. The NiCsNaY catalyst was found to be an almost exclusive dimer selective catalyst and has the lowest deactivation rate.
